abstract_sentences.1: Linguistic typology studies the range of structures present in human language.
abstract_sentences.2: The main goal of the field is to discover which sets of possible phenomena are universal, and which are merely frequent.
abstract_sentences.3: For example, all languages have vowels, while most—but not all—languages have an [u] sound.
abstract_sentences.4: In this paper we present the first probabilistic treatment of a basic question in phonological typology: What makes a natural vowel inventory?
abstract_sentences.5: We introduce a series of deep stochastic point processes, and contrast them with previous computational, simulation-based approaches.
abstract_sentences.6: We provide a comprehensive suite of experiments on over 200 distinct languages.

body_sentences.19: 1182  2 Vowel Inventories and their Typology  Vowel inventories are a simple entry point into the study of linguistic typology.
body_sentences.20: Every spoken language chooses a discrete set of vowels, and the number of vowel phonemes ranges from 3 to 46, with a mean of 8.7 (Gordon, 2016).
body_sentences.21: Nevertheless, the empirical distribution over vowel inventories is remarkably peaked.
body_sentences.22: The majority of languages have 5–7 vowels, and there are only a handful of distinct 4-vowel systems attested despite many possibilities.
body_sentences.23: Reigning linguistic theory (BeckerKristal, 2010) has proposed that vowel inventories are shaped by the principles discussed below.

body_sentences.54: 3 Point Process Models  Given a base set V , a point process is a distribution over its subsets.2 In this paper, we take V to be the set of all IPA symbols corresponding to vowels.

body_sentences.193: 6 Evaluation Metrics  Fundamentally, we are interested in whether our model has abstracted the core principles of what makes a good vowel system.
body_sentences.194: Our choice of a probabilistic model provides a natural test: how surprised is our model by held-out languages?
body_sentences.195: In other words, how likely does our model think unobserved, but attested vowel systems are?
body_sentences.196: While this is a natural evaluation paradigm in NLP, it has not—to the best of our knowledge—been applied to a quantitative investigation of linguistic typology.
body_sentences.197: As a second evaluation, we introduce a vowel system cloze task that could also be used to evaluate non-probabilistic models.
body_sentences.198: This task is defined by analogy to the traditional semantic cloze task (Taylor, 1953), where the reader is asked to fill in a missing word in the sentence from the context.
body_sentences.199: In our vowel system cloze task, we present a learner with a subset of the vowels in a held-out vowel system and ask them to predict the remaining vowels.
body_sentences.200:
Consider, as a concrete example, the
general American English vowel system (excluding long vowels) {[i], [I], [u], [U], [E], [æ], [O], [A], [@]}.
body_sentences.201: One potential cloze task would be to predict {[i], [u]} given {[I], [U], [E], [æ], [O], [A], [@]} and the fact that two vowels are missing from the inventory.
body_sentences.202: Within the cloze task, we report accuracy, i.e., did we guess the missing vowel right?
body_sentences.203: We consider three versions of the cloze tasks.
body_sentences.204: First, we predict one missing vowel in a setting where exactly one vowel was deleted.
body_sentences.205: Second, we predict up to one missing vowel where a vowel may have been deleted.
body_sentences.206: Third, we predict up to two missing vowels, where one or two vowels may be deleted.

body_sentences.235: We regard this as a natural approach to typology, because it directly describes which kinds of linguistic systems are more or less common.

Traditional implicational universals (“all languages with vi have vj”) are softened, in our approach, into conditional probabilities such as “p(vj ∈ V | vi ∈ V ) ≈ 0.9.” Here the 0.9 is not merely an empirical ratio, but a smoothed
probability derived from the complete estimated distribution.
body_sentences.237: It is meant to make predictions about unseen languages.
body_sentences.238: Whether human language learners exploit any properties of this distribution10 is a separate question that goes beyond typology.
body_sentences.239: Jakobson (1941) did find that children acquired phoneme inventories in an order that reflected principles similar to dispersion (“maximum contrast”) and focalization.
body_sentences.240: At any rate, we estimate the distribution given some set of attested systems that are assumed to have been drawn IID from it.
body_sentences.241: One might object that this IID assumption ignores evolutionary relationships among the attested systems, causing our estimated distribution to favor systems that are coincidentally frequent among current human languages, rather than being natural in some timeless sense.
body_sentences.242: We reply that our approach is then appropriate when the goal of typology is to estimate the distribution of actual human languages—a distribution that can be utilized in principle (and also in practice, as we show) to predict properties of actual languages from outside the training set.
body_sentences.243: A different possible goal of typology is a theory of natural human languages.
body_sentences.244: This goal would require a more complex approach.
body_sentences.245: One should not imagine that natural languages are drawn in a vacuum from some single, stationary distribution.
body_sentences.246: Rather, each language is drawn conditionally on its parent language.

body_sentences.251: Liljencrants and Lindblom (1972) propose a coordinate descent algorithm to optimize E(m).
body_sentences.252: While this is not in itself a probabilistic model, they generate diverse vowel systems through random restarts that find different local optima (a kind of deterministic evolutionary mechanism).
body_sentences.253: We note that equation (9) assumes that the number of vowels m is given, and only encodes a notion of dispersion.
body_sentences.254: Roark (2001) subsequently extended equation (9) to include the notion of focalization.
body_sentences.256: A fatal flaw of the traditional energy minimization paradigm is that it has no clear way to compare vowel inventories of different sizes.
body_sentences.257: The problem is quite crippling since, in general, inventories with fewer vowels will have lower energy.
body_sentences.258: This does not match reality—the empirical distribution over inventory sizes (shown in Figure 5) shows that the mode is actually 5 and small inventories are uncommon: no 1-vowel inventory is attested and only one 2-vowel inventory is known.
body_sentences.259: A probabilistic model over all vowel systems must implicitly model the size of the system.
body_sentences.260: Indeed, our models pit all potential inventories against each other, bestowing the extra burden to match the empirical distribution over size.
body_sentences.262: Another problem is the inability to model frequency.
body_sentences.263:
While for inventories of a modest size (3-5 vowels) there are very few unique attested systems, there is a plethora of
attested larger vowel systems.
body_sentences.264: The energy minimization paradigm has no principled manner to tell the scientist how likely a novel system may be.
body_sentences.265: Appealing again to the empirical distribution over attested vowel systems, we consider the relative diversity of systems of each size.
body_sentences.267: Consider all vowel systems of size 7.
body_sentences.268: There are (|V| 7 ) potential inventories, yet the empirical distribution is remarkably peaked.
body_sentences.269: Our probabilistic models have the advantage in this context as well, as they naturally quantify the likelihood of an individual inventory.
body_sentences.271: In contrast to many common problems in applied NLP, e.g., part-of-speech tagging, parsing and machine translation, the modeling of linguistic typology is fundamentally a “small-data” problem.
body_sentences.272: Out of the 7105 languages on earth, we only have linguistic annotation for 2600 of them (Comrie et al., 2013).
body_sentences.273: Moreover, we only have phonetic and phonological annotation for a much smaller set of languages— between 300-500 (Maddieson, 2013).
body_sentences.274: Given the paucity of data, overfitting on only those attested languages is a dangerous possibility—just because a certain inventory has never been attested, it is probably wrong to conclude that it is impossible— or even improbable—on that basis alone.
body_sentences.275: By analogy to language modeling, almost all sentences observed in practice are novel with respect to the training data, but we still must employ a principled manner to discriminate high-probability sentences (which are syntactically and semantically coherent) from low-probability ones.
body_sentences.276: Probabilistic modeling provides a natural paradigm for this sort of investigation—machine learning has developed well-understood smoothing techniques, e.g., regularization with tuning on a held-out dev set, to avoid overfitting in a small-data scenario.
body_sentences.278:
Various point processes have been previously applied to potpourri of tasks
in NLP.
body_sentences.279: Determinantal point processes have found a home in the literature in tasks that require diversity.
body_sentences.280: E.g., DPPs have achieved state-of-the-art results on multi-document document summarization (Kulesza and Taskar, 2011), news article selection (Affandi et al., 2012) recommender systems (Gartrell et al., 2017), joint clustering of verbal lexical semantic properties (Reichart and Korhonen, 2013), inter alia.
body_sentences.281: Poisson point processes have also been applied to NLP problems: Yee et al.
body_sentences.282: (2015) model the emerging topic on social media using a homogeneous point process and Lukasik et al.
body_sentences.283: (2015) apply a log-Gaussian point process, a variant of the Poisson point process, to rumor detection in Twitter.
body_sentences.284: We are unaware of previous attempts to probabilistically model vowel inventory typology.
body_sentences.286: This work lends itself to several technical extensions.
body_sentences.287: One could expand the function f to more completely characterize each vowel’s acoustic properties, perceptual properties, or distinctive features (footnote 7).
body_sentences.288: One could generalize our point process models to sample finite subsets from the continuous space of vowels (footnote 3).
body_sentences.289: One could consider augmenting the MPP with a new factor that explicitly controls the size of the vowel inventory.
body_sentences.290: Richer families of point processes might also be worth exploring.
body_sentences.291: For example, perhaps the vowel inventory is generated by some temporal mechanism with latent intermediate steps, such as sequential selection of the vowels or evolutionary drift of the inventory.
body_sentences.292: Another possibility is that vowel systems tend to reuse distinctive features or even follow factorial designs, so that an inventory with creaky front vowels also tends to have creaky back vowels.
body_sentences.293: 9 Conclusions  We have presented a series of point process models for the modeling of vowel system inventory typology with the goal of a mathematical grounding for research in phonological typology.
body_sentences.294: All models were additionally given a deep parameterization to learn representations similar to perceptual space in cognitive science.
body_sentences.295: Also, we motivated our preference for probabilistic modeling in linguistic typology over previously proposed computational approaches and argued it is a more natural research paradigm.
body_sentences.296: Additionally, we have introduced several novel evaluation metrics for research in vowelsystem typology, which we hope will spark further interest in the area.
body_sentences.297: Their performance was empirically validated on the Becker-Kristal corpus, which includes data from over 200 languages.
